slidelink.displaytext: Time Spent Vs. Timing the Market
The Debt Market and How It Works

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: Blue chips generally sell high-quality, widely accepted products and services. Blue chip companies are known to weather downturns and operate profitably in the face of adverse economic conditions, which helps to contribute to their long record of stable and reliable growth. Investments in such companies are considered to be low risk.
Bonds are allotted by companies in exchange for loans. They usually carry a fixed rate of interest, though in some cases they may not. They can be regular coupon bond or zero coupon bond.

A period of time when stock prices rise is called a bull phase and the trend in this phase is said to be “bullish”. A period of time when stock prices generally fall is called a bear phase and the trend is said to be “bearish”.
An instrument that enables a bank to lend money to another bank without any collateral for a period of just one day.
These are promissory notes issued by banks for a period of seven to 364 days. Other financial institutions can also issue CDs, but only for periods ranging between one to three years.

These are promissory notes issued by corporates for a period of seven to 364 days to meet their short term funding requirements. These are sold at less than their face value and the difference is the profit of the investor. Commercial Paper has to be rated by agencies such as CRISIL.
These are long-term debt instruments issued by corporates for a period of one to 10 years to fund their expansion or growth plans. They can have denominations of as little as Rs 1,000.
This refers to the periodic interest payment made by the issuer to the bondholder of Regular Coupon Bonds. The interest is always paid on the face value.

This refers to the rate at which the interest will be paid. It is defined at the time of issuing and does not change regardless of prevailing interest rates in the market or the performance of the company.

When interest rates are high and an investor sells the bond at less than face value, the price is called “discounted”. Similarly, when rates are high and the investor sells at more than the face value, the price is said to be at a “premium”.

Dividend is the part of the profits earned by a company that it distributes among its shareholders. It is declared as a percentage on the face value of the share. While investing in a company, it’s good to check its dividend policy. Most established companies have an uninterrupted dividend history and share a sizeable part of their profits with investors.
The value amount printed on a security instrument, such as a Rs 10 share, a Rs 500 bond, etc.

A follow-on public offer (FPO) is also called further public offer. When a listed company comes out with a fresh issue of shares or makes an offer for sale to the public to raise funds it is known as FPO.
These are promissory notes for a period of one to 30 years issued by RBI on behalf of the government, as part of the annual borrowing program approved by Parliament in the Budget.

These are bonds for which the coupon, or interest rates are adjusted to increase in inflation rate as determined by the Consumer Price Index (CPI). These help investors to maintain the real value of their invested capital by removing the uncertainty of future inflation rates. Example: Suppose the Index-linked bond is issued with the Face Value of 100 in a year. If inflation rate as per the CPI is 6% for this year, then Maturity Value would be 106.
When a company offers its shares to the public for the first time, the issue is called an Initial Public Offering (IPO)
The tendency of the market to move in a particular direction over a certain time period. The trend rises when stock prices generally increase and falls when prices drop.
The date on which the bond matures and the issuer repays the principal, along with any interest that may be due, to the investor. The maturity date is specified on the bond document.
An instrument that enables a bank to lend money to another bank without any collateral for a period for a period ranging from one to 14 days.

term.title: Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI)

terms.term: SEBI is the regulator of stock markets in the country. It forms rules and regulations for stock trading and continuously monitors it in order to protect the interests of investors.

The Sensex, or sensitivity index, measures the performance of a set of stocks in the market. The BSE Sensex is the weighted index of the top 30 stocks trading on Bombay Stock Exchange. Similarly, the Nifty is the index of the top 50 companies, the BSE 100 is the index of the top 100 companies, etc. The Broad Base index shows the performance of the entire stock market. It serves as a barometer for market behaviour and reflects investor sentiment on the state of the economy.

These are issued by the various state governments to fund their development projects and budget deficit. RBI coordinates the sale of these securities and ensures that each state keeps its borrowings within the prescribed limit.

An organisation that provides a platform on which buyers and sellers of stocks and securities can perform transactions. Although Bombay Stock Exchange is the oldest in the country, all other large cities have their own stock exchanges.
An instrument that enables a bank to lend money to another bank without any collateral for a period of 14 days to one year.
The buying and selling of stocks on the floor of an exchange.

These are issued through the Reserve Bank to meet the short term funding requirements of the government for a period of 91, 182 and 364 days. As these are central government promissory notes, they are considered to be risk-free.
